Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2008 06:15PM jill323 wrote: Hello all !  Add one more to the list for today.  I just completed my first round of Taxol today.  A little wiped and metal taste has already kicked in.   I had no idea there was so much alcohol they gave to give this drug.  I am pretty sure I was drunk in that last hour and slept it off the rest of the afternoon.   Nothing like getting a buzz on at 9 am ! (kidding) Anyway, next round is in three weeks and they are going to mix in the Herceptin at that time.  Today was just to find out how I would react to the Taxol.   I was there about 5 hours due to all the premeds (Emend, Aloxi, Benadryl, Tagamet, Decadron) and the like.  You can tell they are doing a lot to "prevent" side effects.   Feeling a little weak and fatigued right now, but it is manageable.   Going to go back to bed soon.  Hope all the rest of you that had the chemo party today are also doing well ! Jill P.S. The lidocane cream they gave me for the port worked like a dream despite just getting the darn thing put in this past Monday.   I put the cream right over the steri strips, and it still worked !  Did not even feel it when they accessed it !
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 06:16PM jill323 wrote: Ladies - Hi !  Glad to hear folks are doing relatively well.    For the digestive side effects, I have noticed that Metamucil before bed really helps a lot.   It increases fiber content and forces an extra glass of water.   Seems to really have kept away the constipation to diarrhea (and back again) phenomena.   Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 09:14PM jill323 wrote: Mother78 - Hi.  Has your mother mentioned this semi-circle rash to her docs ?   The first thing that popped into my head when I read your post was shingles.  It usually shows up on the trunk of the body and starts working its way around in a circular pattern.  It can be quite painful.   Does this describe the rash or are the individual rash pattern semi-circles ? I have seen some other people that have had shingles as a side effect of chemo.  If that is what you suspect, you might want to have her call her doc. Jill

Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 10:25AM jill323 wrote: Mother78 - Hi.. Try the following link to get to the other thread.  Hope it works for you. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/96/topic/722013?page=2#idx_39 I read your other post as well.  Speaking from my twilight sedation experience, I found it much easier to snap back from that than the general anesthesia from the lumpectomy.   I basically got home and slept for a couple hours and then felt pretty good.  Of course, I am 43 and not 78.   So, not sure my experience would be the same as for your Mom.  However, I know I am a wimp and had no desire to be "awake" for them digging around in my chest.   I have a lot of respect for women who can go the local route, but I know my personal limitations on that.     Everything in this experience has a trade off somewhere.  Just have to decide where your Mom's is.  Anyway, the other piece of advice I can give you is that after getting her port, make sure they get you a prescription for the Emla cream (lidocaine).  Not all docs do this or like to have their patients using this prior to port access, but for a wimp like me, it made a huge difference.  Did not even feel that needle going in despite the still tender surgery site - and honestly that was the part I was dreading most (I know, wimp).  Good luck ! Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 09:11PM jill323 wrote: Sobx - Oh my.  I am really glad you posted tonight.  I am really feeling for you here.  I am not meaning to make light of your situation, but it reads like a breast cancer "country song".  I am really glad I don't live in NC, because if I did, I might be tempted to go to your house and kick your soon to be ex husband.   I had my second treatment today, and this is making me even less forgiving than usual.   What you wrote there made me so angry.  But, my anger is not going to help you. Do you have any other relatives close by ?  Or a Wellness center or something like that ?  We have a Wellness center here in Cincinnati (and it is free), where I go to a local support group.   There was a similar situation happening to one of the ladies in my group, and the rest of us pitched in to really help her out.   Wellness Centers can also can link you up with services that can help in situations like yours - when there is limited support for treatment and the like.   Sometimes local church groups do something similar.  Usually your doctors offices know of groups like this.  It never hurts to ask.  You definitely need some close in support.   I know it is a lot to think about when you are going through so much.  But, you should not have to do this alone.   I know the ladies here will do what they can from afar.  You can also send a private message to me if you really want to know my angry thoughts on this (probably not best idea to post when I am pissed and right after treatment).   But, you really struck a nerve with me on this. Please take care.  The focus needs to be on you right now.  Let us know what is going on.  Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 05:03PM jill323 wrote: Hello everyone !  It sounds like we are all getting through this the best we can !  Suzy - Sorry to hear about all your hospitalizations and the like.   It appears you had your hands full.  Your "absence" is completely understandable.   Hang in there.   Let us know where they come out with your treatment ! As for the flu shot thing.. I specifically asked my onc. about taking a Flu shot and she told me to go ahead and get it, but to make sure I spaced it "in between" treatments.  In other words, get it about a week and a half after my treatment (which would be a week and a half before my next one).  Have to admit, this makes me a little twichty, but so does potentially getting the flu while my immune system is compromised.  Folks in my office are dropping like flies now with all kinds of bugs.  Wondering what the lesser of the two evils is at this point.   Because this makes me nervous, I am going to ask her again, specifically asking the "lesser of two evils" part of it.    But, I suspect like everything else, they likely advise you based on a lot of factors including age, treatment course, etc.   So, we are probably all better off asking our oncs. (Nothing is easy is it ?)   Would be interested if anyone else asked their oncologists about this. Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 11:10AM jill323 wrote: Linda - Hi and welcome.  I just happened to be on line when your post came in.   I know this is a lot to take in.  If you can't tell, unique is quite an inspiration to us all.   So, you couldn't have found a better thread to initiate into.   Unfortunately (of fortunately depending on how you look at it), a lot us are well versed these days on these acronyms.    Because I am in a chemo low today and really want to do something productive, I will take a crack at your acronym question.   ER/PR - This stands for Estrogen and Progesterone Receptors.  If your tumor is highly ER and/or PR positive, it essentially means that female hormones were feeding the tumor.   In this case, there are medicines available to you that can block the hormones that the doc will put you on post treatment.   (If you see the acronym "AI" - that stands for Aromatase Inhibitor - which is one of these types of drugs that block the hormones and/or receptors).  Her2 - Her2 is an "oncogene" that is a characteristic of certain tumor types (about 25% of IDC's).   It is not a very nice guy in that it is essentially like the gasoline that you put on a fire telling the tumor to "grow, grow, grow".    However, as unique mentions, there is a drug, herceptin,  that is available these days that blocks this oncogene and gives those with Her2 positive tumors great stats in terms of recurrence statistics.  "Triple positive" - Means your tumor is positive for ER/PR and Her2 "Triple negative" - Means the tumor is negative for ER/PR and Her2.  This type is typically considered the most difficult to treat because a lot of the therapies available, such as AI's and herceptin won't work.  DCIS/LCIS - Ductal Carcinoma In-Situ/Lobular Carcinoma In-Situ - These are cancer types (some consider pre-cancer) that are basically "contained" within the ducts or lobules of the breast.  This type of cancer does not "travel" in the body.    IDC/ILC - Infiltrating Ductal Carcinoma/Infiltrating Lobular Carcinoma - Indicates a tumor type that started in either the ducts or lobules of the breast and has managed to "break out".  This is the type that can "travel" to other places in the body.   IDC is the most common type.   IBC - Inflammatory breast Cancer - This is a type of advanced breast cancer (about 5-10% are this type) that behaves a little differently than other types.  It usually has some reddening of the skin or pain associated with it. Stage - This is determined by the size of the tumor, the number of lymph nodes involved and whether metasis is present.  Like unique says, stages 0, 1, and 2 are considered "early".  Grade - A measure of how "aggressive" the tumor is.  They determine this by looking at it under a microscope and looking at how rapidly the cells are dividing, what type of cells they are and how far from "normal" the nuclei of the cell look.   Grade 1 is the "lowest" (or least aggressive) grade and Grade 3 is the "highest" (or most aggressive) grade.     There are others, and I know this is a lot to take in.  But, I hope this was helpful.   Thanks for indulging me on my chemo low.  I now feel like I did something productive.   Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 10:25AM jill323 wrote: Linda - Sounds like these ladies took good care of you on this.  You specifically mentioned "over the counter" type stuff, so I am not sure what I am going to mention is useful or not. But, the Emend that Bluedasher mentioned is a very expensive prescription drug.  Even with my decent insurance, two capsules (which is all I need post treatment) runs me about $100.   However, for me, it is worth every penny as it has kept the vomiting/nausea at bay.   I mention it because if your insurance was like mine, two prescriptions of this stuff would eat up the remaining amount of your fund. Jill

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 08:31AM jill323 wrote: Fammy5 - Hi !  Nope.  Basically my case was so "mushy middle" (very small but very aggressive tumor - do they treat small or do they treat aggressive?) that I had two oncologists consulting with each other on this case.   Where we all netted out, (and trust me, this was a negotiation) was that I would do what I call "chemo light" such that I could get the Herceptin in a proven clinical manner given the highly positive Her2 nature of my tumor.  For me, "chemo light" (again, my term because it makes me feel better to call it that), is Taxol.   We are still negotiating number of rounds, but I am hoping for four.   That said, while I am not experiencing overt side effects yet, I don't think any Chemo is "light" - I can tell this thing is going to kick my butt a bit.   Feeling kind of woozy and weak today - and this is before the Nuelasta shot I have to take later today.   You can read my whole sordid story in the IDC forum under a thread titled "Mushy Middle - Different Dr. opinions" if you would like - not that it would be a best selling short story or anything.  But, it does give some additional details of how I got to this strange place.   I am finding there are quite a few of us "mushy middle" ladies out there.   Bluedasher is also one.   Bluedasher - Sorry to hear about your story.  That is really ugly.  Also a bit surprised they told you not to shower.  I was able to shower right after having my surgery due to the dressing they put on.    I have to leave now, but will try to find you later to trade notes.   I did have the twilight sedation, however, so don't know how much any note giving I can provide will help you. Jill

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 02:30PM jill323 wrote: Well... asked the onc. again.  She said that getting the flu was "definitely" the more evil thing while on chemo and that as long as I did not have a fever or showing any other type of signs of infection, to go ahead and get the flu shot.  Said the timing was actually pretty good since I go for my next treatment next Wed.   They were giving flu shots at work today, and I went ahead and got one. That said, I know another lady who goes to the support group I attend, and she told me her doc's office actually gave her the shot before her last chemo treatment - at the same appointment.   So, it appears there are different "philosophies".  Jill

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 11:11AM jill323 wrote: Lynn - Hi.  While I am on the same regimen your mom is on (Taxol/Herceptin), I opted for higher dosages less frequently.   So I am on a three week cycle.    This fit a lot better with my work situation.  My scalp started getting itchy about a week out from treatment and then at about 10 days it started to get real sore.   However, I started lightly "shedding" at the two week mark.   The good thing is that the gray stuff appears to be leaving first !   But, my hair appears "dead".  Kind of flat and lifeless. Anyway, my doc tells me with this regimen, I may or may not lose it entirely.  But, that it will thin for sure.   Unfortunately, I appear to be one of those that will thin more extremely (leave it to me to have over achieving hair in that regard).   I hope that helps. Jill

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 10:10AM jill323 wrote: Hi Kathi, Here it is more like a spring shower than a driving rain storm, but it is noticeable and distracting and my head really hurts.   Last night was the first night I noticed that when I laid my head on my pillow, in certain places it caused my head to hurt (i.e. just to have any sort of "contact" with that part of my scalp).  I kept repositioning myself.    So... like you, I finally am giving in, and getting it cut this morning (sigh...).    In my case, because it is still not clear whether I will lose it all, I am just going for a really short cut.  At least that will keep the "rain" from being quite so noticeable.  But, the hats will come out today.   I learned painfully yesterday that given I have dark hair, not the smartest thing to be wearing a white shirt (what was I thinking?!!).   Everyone kept "brushing" my shoulders off yesterday.   Embarrassing. As for kids, I have only had to deal with my own.  They are 11 and 14.   For the 14 year old, I think the hair thing has been harder for her than it has for me (you know how teen age girls are).   But, one thing I think has helped with her is that I let her be part of the process in picking out hats for me and the like.  She seems to like being able to help.  Jill

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 12:15PM jill323 wrote: Bluedasher - I also saw that study and downloaded the poster of the study.  It was a very clean study with very definitive recommendations.  Basically it said "systemic" treatment was recommended for any Her2 positive infiltrating tumor, regardless of size.   There was not even a difference between T1a (less than 0.5 cm) and T1b (0.5-1.0 cm) tumors in terms of recurrence risk - the definitive factor was Her2.   I took it into my doc when I went in for my regular appointment.  She had not seen it yet and was practically dancing in her office when I showed it to her as it validated her recommendation and the choice I made as well.   She said this study would likely change some treatment protocols out there - especially for small and Her2 positive tumors.    Would have liked to have had this study four months ago... , but regardless, glad I (and you) ended up making the choice that was on the right side of the stats.   There is something to be said for gut and intuition, but nice to see it validated by data. What do you know, not "mushy middle" any more ! Jill
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 06:49PM jill323 wrote: jillisucat - Hello from another Jill !   I also had IDC diagnosed via mammogram, also discovered by microcalcifications.   First, let me tell you what microcalcifications are.  As the pathologist explained it to me, when there are bunches of microcalcifications branching/clustering in the ducts, it usually indicates rapidly dividing cells that are dying quickly.   In other words, the microcalcifications are the byproduct of dying cancer cells.  Basically, they are dividing too fast to set up an adequate blood supply, which is why some of them die.  In my case, there was also no "lump" that was discernable.  However, they are able to pinpoint where these cells are via biopsy (assuming they left a clip in you from the biopsy) and via other tecniques such as MRI.   In my case, they were able to remove the offending cells and in looking at it under the microscope determined there were two little clusters of cells measuring 1 cm and 2.5 cm in diameter of DCIS, but unfortunately, a 4 mm diameter cluster of IDC.  You could see why no one could "feel" a 4 mm cluster of cells. In any case, usually when they find this via microcalcifications, it means it was caught very early.  So, that is relatively good news !   As for the other breast, weirdly, I had the same thing happen.  My right one was the "offending" one, but I got super sensitive about the left one.  However, it turned out to be nothing in my case.  I ended up attributing it to stress. However, I am assuming that they will get you a pre-op MRI - and they will get a good look at both breasts when they do that.  So, not to worry !   In any case, I have been where you are now.  Did the lumpectomy and am now in chemo then off to radiation.   In my case, the IDC was little but not very nice (aggressive markers).  However, this is not the case with all IDC.   In fact, my case is a little unusual in that regard.   So, feel free to contact me at any time.  I am nearly expert at reading a pathology report now !  Lots of ladies on the board will support you through this !   I know this is a club you did not want to join (no one does), but once you are here, you are "family". Jill

Let us know how you are doing.  Like I said, we have been there.  I benefited from the experience of the ladies on this board.  We hope to do the same for you.  The other Jill

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 05:35PM jill323 wrote: Kathy - Hi again.   First, glad to see your husband is going with you to your appointment.  Make sure he takes notes.  That will help.   A lot of information will be thrown your way.  I also vividly recall those "waiting days".   It is REALLY hard.    But, really... it is the hardest part - mainly because waiting allows for "what if" - which then usually leads to all kinds of scenarios in your head.    AND, BTW, don't psyche yourself out with all the stuff on the internet.  That just makes it worse.  This then lends itself to upsetting those around you because no one wants to see someone you love upset. So... a couple of things that helped me when I started this.  1) With the advances in breast cancer treatment even over the past couple years - our prognoses are better than ever.   This might sound a little crass (and forgive me if it does), but when I got this, I thought.. well, if I gotta get cancer, at least I got the "right" kind.   What I mean by that is that this type has so much attention and research dollars toward it these days, the survival rates have increased and recurrence risks have dropped dramatically.  There are other types of cancer whose prognosis is a whole lot worse.  Even just five years ago my type of tumor (Her2+++) was considered to be almost guaranteed to come back.  Today, with the advances like herceptin, the chances of it ever coming back have dropped amazingly.  2) My aunt is a 23 year breast cancer survivor.  She was treated at the exact same age I am right now when the technologies were not nearly as advanced.  By God, if she could do it, so can I.  3)  Look at the sheer numbers on this board.   While it is depressing to think about all these ladies (and some men) having breast cancer - the fact they are here says you are not alone.   Many of these women are doing great today and are real life heroines in my eyes.   4) I have seen a number of women on this board start asking the question of "what did I do wrong" - as if somehow we did something to cause this.   I have learned over time that you will make yourself crazy doing that.   There is no explanation that you can put your finger on - not HRT, not your crazy lifestyle in your 20s, not your lack of mammograms, etc.   No one did anything to deserve this and to suggest otherwise blames the victim.   So.. start putting your energy toward where you need it - focus on the end game which is kicking this thing.   Some practical suggestions now...  lots of communities have local Wellness Community Centers where you can join a local support group.  I have found them to be a great source of information and comfort.   I really look forward to time I spend with these ladies.   If your town does not have that, check with your doc's office.  They sometimes know of local organizations who do similar things. In order to start turning your energy toward the end game, start thinking about very practical things like...  taking time off of work (if you work) and how you want to go about that (DB, vacation), how or whether you want to inform family members, co-workers etc.  In other words, wait out the waiting game by occupying yourself with other things that will focus your energy toward not letting yourself be a victim of this little monster.  While it might sound cliche, we really do acquire strength in what we overcome.  You are on the start of a journey that none of us wanted to be on.  But, think of it as a journey that has a defined and glorious end point - which is being cancer free.  It will be bumpy and scary at times and your path and milestones are just now being defined.   But, you can do this.   Attitude really is a big enabler.  Now.. hang in there.  I hoped this helped even a little.  We will support you throughout. I look forward to hearing what your breast surgeon says.   Jill
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 07:23AM jill323 wrote: Kathy - Hi.  I am sorry you have to go through this.   I completely understand the freaking out thing.  But, breathe... you will get through this.   And no.. you are not an idiot.  No one plans to get this - mammograms or not.   Sometimes we are just going about living our lives and stuff happens.    I will give you the "Reader's Digest" version of your pathology.  Basicially it is saying that you have "invasive" cancer.  There is not enough in your report to say whether it is ductal or lobular invasive cancer.  But, they will tell you that.   "Invasive" means that the cancer has managed to break out of where it started - like the ducts or the lobules of the breat.   An "in situ component"   is the type of cancer that stays put either in the ducts or lobules of the breast - i.e. it has not broken out yet.   You don't have any of that that has been identified.   MANY women have both types at the same time - an insitu component and an invasive component.   I am an example of that I had both IDC (which is invasive ductal carcinomia) and DCIS  (which is the insitu component).    "Poorly differentiated" means the cells look very different from normal cells - which means you are likely looking at a Grade 2 or 3 cancer.    This means it is a little more aggressive.  All the stuff about "hemmorrhagic" and "inflammation" basically means that when they drained the "cyst" earlier, it irritated the site.   That is pretty typical.   Good news that no evidence of lymphovascular invasion.  Hopefully that means the cancer has not ventured out to the lymph nodes.  Does not mean that for sure, but it is a good sign. Sending out for ER/PR and Her2 testing is very typical.  This means they will send out your sample for characterization.   What they will be looking for is estrogen receptors (ER), and progesterone receptors (PR).  Doing this lets them know if female hormones were "feeding" your tumor.   Her2/neu is a "protein" that characterizes about 20% of tumors (I am Her2 positive).   Having all this characterization will determine your treatment course.  Finally, they are recommending taking a good look at it for Medullary Carcinoma.  This is a more rare type of breast cancer that is characterized by its color.  However, the good news with that is that this type is usually considered to have a better prognosis. So.... what does all this mean ?    It means that they caught this - and this is a good thing (even if they did get it wrong at first).     The breast surgeon will go over your options based on a lot of factors including the expected size of the tumor, the location, etc.    You are likely looking at a lumpectomy or a mastectomy depending on those factors and your personal choices.   (You will also likely be sent for an MRI at some point).    The treatment course after that is determined by a LOT of things - charcteristics of your tumor, the surgery route you chose, your age, your menopausal status.   You will find there is not one size to fit all these days. Just take it one day at a time.  Get as much information as you can and ask as many questions of your doctors as you can to best understand your situation.  That is what they are there for.   While this will be a very bumpy time in your life, there have been lots of us down this path - and are doing pretty well these days.   We understand and can support you.    Also.. remember.. waiting is the hardest part.  Once you get rolling and into treatment, it will be easier to focus and move forward.  So, hang in there - you can do this.   You can also feel free to Private message me if you need additional information or just want to bounce some other things off of me.  Best of luck to you.  Jill
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38
